pull_request.title: Hide our misuses of contexts from the public interface
pull_request.body: Our `context` package is a big pile of sadness which breaks most of the context usage rules and encourages bad practices. And tragically our bad habits around contexts have leaked into a couple of our extension-point interfaces: `auth.AccessController` and `storage.StorageDriver`. Modify the interfaces such that implementations are no longer required to abuse contexts, and unexport the pile of sadness.

pull_request.title: cleanup: make chunk sizes easier to understand and change writer append
pull_request.body:
This tiny PR makes the S3 driver chunk size constants more straightforward to understand -- instead of remembering the bit shifts we make this more explicit.

We are also updating `appendParam` of the `(writer).Write` to follow the new convention we are trying to establish: `appendMode`.

pull_request.title: cleanup: a small Azure driver cleanup
pull_request.body:
Just so we can make the code a bit more consistent with the rest of the storage drivers.

Most of the updates in this PR are stylistic so the code across the drivers is more consistent in style.

Additions:
* compile time interface checks for `driver` and `writer`
* made some error messages a bit shorter
* there are a few TODO comments around retries, concurrency (in writer - we set similar parameter in S3 driver to `100`) and some `if` condition checks

PTAL @corhere

comment.body:
I am not sure we need this here as `newWriter` returns `storagedriver.FileWriter`. We do add this check in the `gcs` driver so we should maybe remove it from there.

Though we should probably prefer returning struct types and not interfaces 🤔

issue.title: refactor: gcs storage driver
issue.body:
This refactors GCS storage driver from the ground up and makes it a bit more consistent with the rest of the storage drivers.

Notably, the `writer` now contains a reference to the `driver` in a similar fashion the S3 writer is implemented.

Some of the "helper" funcs were removed and others were made methods on specific GCS driver objects. This simplifies the code quite a bit and gets it more aligned with other storage driver implementations in this repository. 

**NOTE:** There is more work to be done but I figured this could be a first step hence the PR is marked as a _DRAFT_ at the moment

CC: @flavianmissi @jmontleon @kaovilai since you were the OG authors of the recent GCS driver update. Would you mind having a look and if you have a way to test it somewhere in GCS that'd be grand. I've only done some local "simulation" tests.

comment.body:
> I just noticed that [calling func (*BucketHandle) Retryer with no arguments is a no-op.](https://pkg.go.dev/cloud.google.com/go/storage#BucketHandle.Retryer) And on the topic of retries, I don't think [the Google Cloud SDK defaults](https://pkg.go.dev/cloud.google.com/go/storage#hdr-Retrying_failed_requests)

So this is my misunderstanding of the docs again 🤦‍♂️: my assumption was that the _default retries_ you're mentioning only apply when you call `Retryer()` without any arguments (assuming that the retrier applies the defaults described in that section. I'm wondering how much of my garbage code coulda been avoid if I didn't constantly misuderstand the docs 🤣

> What should we do about retries? I'm tempted to simply leave SDK retry defaults alone, wrap the putContent calls in Cancel() and Close() with retry() and declare that the different retry behaviour with Reader is a feature. And delete all the no-op .Retryer() calls.

I'd be ok with this, yeah.

Btw, I'm also not sure how I feel about indefinite retries, but then docs say:

> To stop retries from continuing, use context timeouts or cancellation. 

So if the API clients are set up properly this should be ok 🤔

issue.title: Hide our misuses of contexts from the public interface

milestone.title: Registry/3.0.0
milestone.description: This milestone tracks Distribution v3.0.0 release which does not have a set release date, yet.

issue.body: Our `context` package is a big pile of sadness which breaks most of the context usage rules and encourages bad practices. And tragically our bad habits around contexts have leaked into a couple of our extension-point interfaces: `auth.AccessController` and `storage.StorageDriver`. Modify the interfaces such that implementations are no longer required to abuse contexts, and unexport the pile of sadness.

comment.body: I've pushed changes as fixup commits for your reviewing convenience. Don't worry about the failed DCO check: I'll [autosquash](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-rebase#Documentation/git-rebase.txt---autosquash) the offending fixup commits away after review.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@
+package requestutil
+
+import (
+	"net"
+	"net/http"
+	"strings"
+
+	log "github.com/sirupsen/logrus"
+)
+
+func parseIP(ipStr string) net.IP {
+	ip := net.ParseIP(ipStr)
+	if ip == nil {
+		log.Warnf("invalid remote IP address: %q", ipStr)
comment.body: I went to go plumb contexts through (from `(*http.Request).Context()`) but realized that requestutil importing dcontext would be an import cycle as dcontext already imports requestutil. Frankly the requestutil functions are not amazing (parse the IP address only to throw away the parsed form and return the source string representation?!) so I think that the the import cycle would best be broken by redesigning the requestutil functions such that the caller can do the logging, if it chooses to.

repo.name: distribution
repo.description: The toolkit to pack, ship, store, and deliver container content

review.body:
I just noticed that [calling `func (*BucketHandle) Retryer` with no arguments is a no-op.](https://pkg.go.dev/cloud.google.com/go/storage#BucketHandle.Retryer) And on the topic of retries, I don't think [the Google Cloud SDK defaults](https://pkg.go.dev/cloud.google.com/go/storage#hdr-Retrying_failed_requests) are sufficient to replace our `retry()` function.
- The default retry policy is `RetryIdempotent`. [Object uploads are conditionally idempotent](https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/retry-strategy) so the SDK will only retry when a precondition is set, which we do not.
- The default backoff parameters might not match up with the backoff parameters our `retry()` function uses
- Our `retry()` function gives up after five attempts. The SDK will generally keep retrying indefinitely, until the context is canceled, [though there are some important exceptions.](https://pkg.go.dev/cloud.google.com/go/storage#Writer:~:text=//%20ChunkRetryDeadline%20sets%20a,time.Duration)

Fortunately(?) the pre-refactor gcs driver also left the SDK retry configuration at default, which means that the SDK retry was always in play in some cases, and the `retry()` wrappers around idempotent operations (`storageStatObject`) were not doing anything. Unfortunately the pre-refactor gcs driver implemented `Reader` with raw HTTP requests so would give up after five attempts to get a chunk, whereas the post-refactor implementation will retry indefinitely. On the other hand, `GetContent` would have always retried indefinitely so maybe it's not such a big deal for `Reader` to now behave the same?

Pre-refactor, `func (*writer) Cancel` and `func (*writer) Close` would retry the writes up to five times. Post refactor, no retries at all as the SDK wouldn't consider them idempotent. 

What should we do about retries? I'm tempted to simply leave SDK retry defaults alone, wrap the `putContent` calls in `Cancel()` and `Close()` with `retry()` and declare that the different retry behaviour with `Reader` is a feature. And delete all the no-op `.Retryer()` calls.

pull_request.title: refactor: gcs storage driver
pull_request.body:
This refactors GCS storage driver from the ground up and makes it a bit more consistent with the rest of the storage drivers.

Notably, the `writer` now contains a reference to the `driver` in a similar fashion the S3 writer is implemented.

Some of the "helper" funcs were removed and others were made methods on specific GCS driver objects. This simplifies the code quite a bit and gets it more aligned with other storage driver implementations in this repository. 

**NOTE:** There is more work to be done but I figured this could be a first step hence the PR is marked as a _DRAFT_ at the moment

CC: @flavianmissi @jmontleon @kaovilai since you were the OG authors of the recent GCS driver update. Would you mind having a look and if you have a way to test it somewhere in GCS that'd be grand. I've only done some local "simulation" tests.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -92,11 +93,10 @@ type StorageDriver interface {
 	// Delete recursively deletes all objects stored at "path" and its subpaths.
 	Delete(ctx context.Context, path string) error
 
-	// URLFor returns a URL which may be used to retrieve the content stored at
-	// the given path, possibly using the given options.
-	// May return an ErrUnsupportedMethod in certain StorageDriver
-	// implementations.
-	URLFor(ctx context.Context, path string, options map[string]interface{}) (string, error)
+	// RedirectContent returns a URL which the client of the request r may use
+	// to retrieve the content stored at path. Returning the empty string
+	// signals that the request may not be redirected.
+	RedirectContent(r *http.Request, path string) (string, error)

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -92,11 +93,10 @@ type StorageDriver interface {
 	// Delete recursively deletes all objects stored at "path" and its subpaths.
 	Delete(ctx context.Context, path string) error
 
-	// URLFor returns a URL which may be used to retrieve the content stored at
-	// the given path, possibly using the given options.
-	// May return an ErrUnsupportedMethod in certain StorageDriver
-	// implementations.
-	URLFor(ctx context.Context, path string, options map[string]interface{}) (string, error)
+	// RedirectContent returns a URL which the client of the request r may use
+	// to retrieve the content stored at path. Returning the empty string
+	// signals that the request may not be redirected.
+	RedirectContent(r *http.Request, path string) (string, error)
comment.body:
The function's semantics are more (subtle) than just what is returned. It is not simply returning "the" URL for the content. The driver is dictating _whether_ a particular request for content should be redirected, and if so, where to redirect that request to. The s3 and gcs drivers return a different URL depending on the request's HTTP verb. The cloudfront storage middleware decides whether or not to redirect the request by examining the request's source IP.

I had picked the name `RedirectContent` to draw parallels to `GetContent` and `PutContent`, though now looking at it with fresh eyes I realize that the comparison is more likely to confuse than inform readers. What do you think of the name `RedirectURL`?

And tragically our bad habits around contexts have leaked into a couple of our extension-point interfaces: `auth.AccessController` and `storage.StorageDriver`. Modify the interfaces such that implementations are no longer required to abuse contexts, and unexport the pile of sadness.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@
+package requestutil
+
+import (
+	"net"
+	"net/http"
+	"strings"
+
+	log "github.com/sirupsen/logrus"
+)
+
+func parseIP(ipStr string) net.IP {
+	ip := net.ParseIP(ipStr)
+	if ip == nil {
+		log.Warnf("invalid remote IP address: %q", ipStr)
comment.body: Nobody thought to plumb the context through before, I guess. Without a populated context to pull values from, `dcontext.Logger` would yield the same result as raw logrus logging calls with extra steps.
